snippet.textDisplay:
I have never played the game, I'm only interested in video game music, and Chrono Trigger is one of my favourite sound tracks for a game ever. And I particularly love this piece.


Not only was this composed at a time where hardware limitations were a real thing, Mitsuda managed to engineer sounds which make his music feel truly organic at times; and this track is an example (the best example to me, though, remains "Secret of the Forest"). Not only that, but he has a knack for not only melodies but rhythm...


As far as video game music is concerned, to me, Mitsuda only yields to that VGM stablemate which is Uematsu.
snippet.textOriginal:
I have never played the game, I'm only interested in video game music, and Chrono Trigger is one of my favourite sound tracks for a game ever. And I particularly love this piece.


Not only was this composed at a time where hardware limitations were a real thing, Mitsuda managed to engineer sounds which make his music feel truly organic at times; and this track is an example (the best example to me, though, remains "Secret of the Forest"). Not only that, but he has a knack for not only melodies but rhythm...


As far as video game music is concerned, to me, Mitsuda only yields to that VGM stablemate which is Uematsu.

snippet.textDisplay: Esta música me hace reflexionar que la vida es corta e interesante, un momento que podemos considerar monótono es y será siempre un momento, no le podríamos sacar esa característica por más mal que la hayamos pasado en aquel momento. Aún así después de tantos "momentos" se puede sacar una conclusión parcial del pasado y en mi caso, la vida no ha sido tan mala simplemente la interpreto con desinterés o desconfianza, han pasado tantas emociones, tantos lloriqueos, tantas risas, tantas muertes que no me queda nada más que agradecer a la vida en reflexión nostálgica. Aprendamos de la vida que es de lo poco que nos queda en este nihilismo capitalista, vale la pena echarse un rato a pensar y rememorar lo bello.

Definitely some very good games that I'd consider art

Hollow Knight is VERY good, and something I'd consider art without a whole lot of story dragging it down
The Ori games are also really good, though with a greater focus on story but that's few a d far between, and the games are absolutely gorgeous

for me, it was back in 1996. 
I was looking around in a game shop when I stumbled upon Chrono Trigger on the corner shelves... I was so mesmerized, I played only Chrono Trigger for the next few months.

snippet.textDisplay:
To me it was probably because of the sense of adventure that sparkled in my fragile little 9 year old mind. I remember exactly how I felt the first time I went to the middle ages: a mix between a lowkey fear and curiosity. We were alone in what resembled our own era, but could very much be seen as an entirely different world in comparison to what we knew. The future was bleak, but a blank page. Uncertain, but exciting. And this was probably the moment I was hooked on Chrono Trigger and decided I needed to finish it, no matter what.
Ah man, how I miss my childhood. But it feels good remembering it :)

snippet.textDisplay:
+Luke Fon Fabre If I had to hazard a guess as to why this theme grabs so many people is that the era of 600 AD and the first 44 seconds harken back to a bygone time. A time when we're told that things were simple and good. But, traveling there themself Chrono and the player see that 600 AD was far from that. Wracked by war and the fear of imminent destruction at the hands of the Magi humanity is barely fending them off. Humanity's victory paints the age in a light of dominance, supremacy, and the victory of their hopes which leads to a rosy interpretation of the events. All of this is interpreted and evoked by the pure emotionality of music in its score. It starts off simple with a few plucks, but then starts to gain more in a deep melody, just in time to enjoy that the song breaks into an almost sad aria, and is then plunged into a muddled and possibly feckless jumble, but it ends in this incredibly powerful and hopeful harmonious resolution, and then goes back to the happy part.

Also... Frog's from this era. And Frog is a bad-ass.

snippet.textDisplay: +MST R Unfortunately, I think it would be pretty terrible as an anime/movie.  I really like Chrono Trigger as a game but it's story isn't anything spectacular if you think about it.  I do think the way it's paced throughout the game is fantastic. The game has bosses, enemies, side quests, and dungeons that set apart each story sequence so you feel motivated to advance through the game in order to see what the next plot point is. Another advantage of the game is that you, as the player, were experiencing everything yourself so you felt a sense of discovery as the plot unraveled.  However, if you imagine how it'd be like in, say, an anime, just imagine how the plot will run through everything.  You're just watching the story of Chrono Trigger, which is essentailly a couple of teenagers, a frog, a robot, a cavewoman, and (possibly) a sorceror saving the world from an evil alien.  Plus, Chrono will talk...

snippet.textDisplay:
Also you have to point out, Chrono Trigger are like one of the few games that pushed themselves to the limit (there are few others, either gameplay-wise, or graphical such as Toy Story for the SNES, with "3D" graphics that actually looked 3D, or some that involved a lot of atmosphere - musical or gameplay)
Nowadays, it's very, very hard to push a game to the limit of what was the game made on/for, on the SNES and other older consoles, they had low limitation when it came to graphics, coding, and even music / sound effects, so what they mostly did was combine/interact sound effects with others to create a whole new thing, leaving some space for other things i guess...

Honesly, if time machines could exist, if you tell to someone in the 70's that in the future, games will have a way to interact with it in real life - with real-time response to movement ("kinetic" games), or that you could almost literally BE the character themselves in the game, in their own perspective and even do their actions (first Oculus Rift and then we got VR), They'd very likely laugh and call you crazy.

snippet.textDisplay:
you guys seem to think that time/graphics/music/heart w/e matters... it really really doesn't. a good game is a good game, a bad hearted designer can create a master piece, and a good hearted designer can still create shyt... what matters is if it speaks to the heart of the person playing everything else is pretty irrelevant... i heared a lot of shit talk about FF15, i personally enjoyed the game for what it is... i personally hate call of duty but if you enjoy it, who am i too tel you off, hell i think its amazing u can find joy in something that i dislike...

i think the importand thing here is: chrono trigger stood out too many of us because it did something more impressive then what the current gaming scene seems to do... IT FIGHTS its limitations... it why many games of the time were so impressive, they fought the limitations of the system, today a game designer has so much choice, but they just dont use it, instead many games sell by a few gimmicks, or by a graphical improvement... that is why i think so many people love the older FFs over the newer FFs, or why people preffer chrono trigger over chrono cross...

still too say no good games are made anymore is too spit in the face of good games like world of final fantasy or final fantasy 15, they are good games in their own right even if they dont cap off the systems capabilities :D

snippet.textDisplay:
@joel6113 "Link between worlds" really? You're listing the game that is a blatant re-hash and ripoff of Link to the Past as having any kind of merits when someone could literally just play LttP and get the same experience 15 years ago?
Not to mention nearly every game you've listed here, aside from Dark Souls and Bastion, is _hardly_ the kind of enduring classic Chrono Trigger and Chrono Cross were -- and more than that, they're being deliberately retro in a gimmicky attempt to capture the goodwill of gamers who played true masterpieces like CT and CC as well as all the other incredible titles history has produced.
No one said that ALL games are shit these days, but the truth is that even so-called "good" games in the modern age of triple-a ultra-graphic lens-flare dubstep zombie repetetiveness are usually just imitations or re-imaginings of old games and mechanics introduced back in the golden age of console gaming.
Exceptions to this exist, as I noted above. Bastion and especially Demons' Souls are wonderful examples of games that really brought something new and fresh to the table, which is awesome and we should all be happy about that. However, someone making the true assertion that a huge percentage of modern games are soulless triple-a cash grabs milking fucking stupid 13 year olds out of their money shouldn't be met with criticism just because "NUH UH, THESE GAMES ARE GOOD AND THEREFORE TOTALLY OUTWEIGH THE HUGE TUMOR THAT'S KILLING GAME DEVELOPMENT SPIRIT AND GAMES AS A MEDIUM!"

snippet.textDisplay:
+KefkaJr Have you played Journey? Ori and the Blind Forest? Shovel Knight? A Link Between Worlds? Titan Souls? Any of the Dark Souls games? Bastion? Transistor? Terraria? Xenoblade Chronicles?


Those are games from the last 10 years that I've played that have either a "sense of mystery and discovery" or that made me "feel like I was being invited to a world", as you put it. I've also heard great things about some other games, like Witcher 3, although I don't really have time for a game that vast right now. I've also heard really good things about Undertale, which I've heard is a very good game inspired by and very similar to Earthbound - in which case it should be great.


Many of them live up to Chrono Trigger, although they obviously can't be directly compared due to genre differences. Not to mention that Chrono Trigger was a great game compared to the old games as well. Also, lacking mystery or a good world doesn't make a game bad. Look at the Dota and League and Starcraft and the other MOBA and RTS type games - they completely lack all of that, but definitely top many peoples list of greatest games of all time. Different strokes for different folks.

snippet.textDisplay: @Jellybean I believe it is more about the direction the heart is taking. There are still games that capture the majesty of the old titles, but too many games today lack the substance that so many games were forced to once have. Years ago they didn't have a lot to work with and so they made due with what they did have: Creativity, storytelling, and sheer spirit. Almost everything today is balances with the simple necessity of improved graphics and monetary gain, barring very few workable titles. Graphics are wonderful, but the reasons stand against the tests of time on why Chrono Trigger is rated among the best video games of all-time.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't have a copy for the Super Nintendo, I rented it. But I bought it for the PS1 AND the nintendo DS. If they come out with another copy on another system, you can bet I'll buy that one too! Yes, I've already beaten it at least 5 times on every system I've played it on over the years, but this is the one game that I can play 100 times and still not get tired of it. Best art, best story, best music, best game ever.

snippet.textDisplay: And the fact that you, and the rest of us, have those moments to look back on is what makes being able to experience those moments worth more than anything else you'll find in the world. I'm 25 myself, and quite frankly this music, while making miss the times where I first played this game as a child, makes me reminisce about being a kid, and playing this game, and hearing this music. And in a small moment in my busy, stressful adult life, I can go back to being a kid again, if for a few minutes

snippet.textDisplay:
Okay, am I the only one who gets really, really nostalgic to where I lose the will to move forward? When I reminisce about the good old days of playing RPGs like this without any worries or cares in the world, I just want to go back. I want to relive my memories 
: (

I am only 26 and already want to rewind time. I get really sad thinking of the beautiful times I've had in games and irl. I want time to stop more than anything.

snippet.textDisplay:
indeed, I feel so lucky that I noticed Chrono Trigger for the DS, because it's such a great game especially for a medium where graphics don't really matter. The first moment I started playing the game was at the beginning of a long car trip. I stopped playing 10 hours later when we got home.
And what you said about the movement of the old grand RPG's with stories is true but don't forget that there are also new (tactical) RPG's that are really good like The World Ends With You and many others.

Budgets these days all go towards graphics - not saying that it's even superior because of it -  and they wonder why gamers these days just binge 24 hours through games and forget what they played just days ago. Go indie!

snippet.textDisplay:
I never played this game.
Heard it was a great game, so I bought it on the DS a couple years ago.
I played it, and then I stopped for a while.
I'm amazed at the power of these compositions, I've only played this game for a bit, and the music is already Nostalgic. I'm happy that's possible.
Same thing goes to the Infinite Undiscovery Soundtrack for me! I never played the game though, just listened to its beautiful soundtrack. 
:') Tears of Nostalgia, you'll know it soon enough.

snippet.textDisplay: Holy shit many words here. Anyway, to finish, the last trend I don't fully appreciate about newer consoles and developers in particular is their attempts to integrate multiplayer and online social functionality. Perhaps it's because it's the way I got used to things as I grew up, but when I play console games, I play them for single player, unless they're beat 'em ups or I'm playing with friends. If I want to play online, it's typically competitive, and almost exclusively on PC.
snippet.textOriginal: Holy shit many words here. Anyway, to finish, the last trend I don't fully appreciate about newer consoles and developers in particular is their attempts to integrate multiplayer and online social functionality. Perhaps it's because it's the way I got used to things as I grew up, but when I play console games, I play them for single player, unless they're beat 'em ups or I'm playing with friends. If I want to play online, it's typically competitive, and almost exclusively on PC.

snippet.textDisplay: Not only that, but the focus seems to be shifting towards a more cinematic presentation, and emphasis seems to be placed on being 'immersive'. I dunno, it just feels like some modern games feel different to what I originally became interested in games for. Possibly that also explains the differences of opinion found between different kinds of younger gamers, too, as there are still praiseworthy modern releases, just need to, uh, 'navigate'.

snippet.textDisplay: The problem with modern games, in my opinion, is that they are so commercialised that it inhibits the kind of spontaneous creativity or whimsy in the older games that, in my opinion, is part of their charm. ("THE WORLD IS SQUARE", or the dialogue in the entire city of Zeal, for example)

snippet.textDisplay: Wish I could've played this as a younger child. FFVII was, alas, my first experience, though also amazing. Played this for the first time at 14 or 15 or so as I was running out of old classics to emulate and it was held in very high esteem, and rightly so. It's difficult to be fanatical about it like some are, but it's still among the best RPGs I've played to date.

snippet.textDisplay: Some of the sounds used in the SNES version are not so easy to recreate with a live orchestra, which makes me prefer the SNES version. For instance, I doubt a live orchestra would use a clave with a delay effect for the 'clock-ticking' sound for the first part of the song. Most of the other Chrono songs also blend electric keyboards and other rock instruments as well, which seems to be an RPG trademark.
snippet.textOriginal: Some of the sounds used in the SNES version are not so easy to recreate with a live orchestra, which makes me prefer the SNES version. snippet.textDisplay: Chrono Trigger was mainly composed by Yasunori Mitsuda. Towards the end of the project, Mitsuda's hard drive took a shit and he lost something like 40 half-finished pieces. After this, Mitsuda started getting ulcers, and Nobou Uematsu was brought in to help finish the soundtrack. I don't know who composed which piece, but Mitsuda was the primary creator.
snippet.textOriginal: Chrono Trigger was mainly composed by Yasunori Mitsuda. Towards the end of the project, Mitsuda's hard drive took a shit and he lost something like 40 half-finished pieces. After this, Mitsuda started getting ulcers, and Nobou Uematsu was brought in to help finish the soundtrack. I don't know who composed which piece, but Mitsuda was the primary creator.

I love graphics, and while they don't make a game (My favourite of all time is Diablo 2 and to be honest it looks like shit these days, but I still play it) they can make playing the game a lot more fun.

Obviously Chrono Trigger doesn't look as good anymore. However, it's still a fucking good game, and while the graphics aren't that pleasing, the soundtrack is one of the best of all time. This song is amazing, and no level of sound quality is going to change that basic fact.

snippet.textDisplay: you can't re-make the magic of a Super Nintendo on a handheld system. I'm sorry, you just can't. When I turn on my TV, I guarantee that as long as your screen is clear, SNES games still have the smoothest animation, the best sound, and that classic gameplay that just can't be done anywhere else. Sure, plenty of systems and games have come out since them displaying monumental graphics, sound, and (sadly, not much) gameply advancements, but Super Nintendo has stood the test of time for what it is.
